div.p: TUESDAY, MAY 16. 1905. THE RUSSIAN FLEET. The embarrassment caused by the presenoe of the Baltic Squadron in the Far Eastern waters shows few signs of diminution, and tho news which we receive to-day from Tokio is not likely to allay the tension which undoubtedly prevails. “It is positively affirm ed (says Renter) that the Baltic Fleet left Honkohe temporarily under French pressure, but it has alone returned and remains there." It is perfectly obvious therefore that France has disregarded the strong protest from Tokio and continues to give asylum to the fleet of her ally. The semi-official vindication of the French attitude which was published last weak cannot be described as a very convincing doon- ment. It is directed against the censored message" from Hong Kong, the appearance of which caused so grave an impression, and for the first time made us realise how grave were the breaches of neutrality that had ooourred. The “dementi" somewhat baldly asserts that not only has the French Government not been at tanlt as regards the rules of neutrality, “but, after having sent to its agents, both civil and military, very precise instructions for the application of those rules, it has not oeased to direct its efforts to their execution.” Reply- ing to M. de Pressens4 in the French Cham- ber yesterday, M. Rouvier declared that he had nothing to add to the previous expla- nations ; “he could only repeat that he had ordered the authorities in the Far Eiat to sec that neutrality was strictly observed.’' Nothing could be more vague or general, especially when the minute particulars given by LkffanV correspondent are remembered. He asserted from hi* own personal observation made on a That no such untoward incident has yet taken place is due to various causes. We be- lieve Japan to be sincerely reluctant to enlarge the sphere of operations and to bring about what would inevitably be a very delicate situation between Great Britain and Franoe. And Japan farther recognises the extreme embarrassment of the position into which France has been allowed to drift by her Govern- ment From want of firmness at the beginning, and from inability to realise the fall conse- qnenoee of the laxity shown in her colonial ports, France is now between two fires; between an injured and exasperated Japan and a Russia which is resolved to push the oom- plaisancy of her ally to the last extremity. During the long sojourn of Rodjestvensky at Nossi Bb, and in the light of the protests of Japan and the comments of the Anglo-Saxon Press, the French Government had ample time to concert a plan of action against the next appearance of Russian warships in French territorial waters. Nothing of the kind was attempted, and the analogy of Madagascar has been exactly followed at Kamaranh Bay. But even if France had been more desirous of discharging her duties as a neutral, the culpable weakness of the French Navy in the Far East would have made its difficult task. With the resources at her disposal it becomes a difficult matter to prevent abuse of harbours and of telegraphic stations on French territory. France has much to learn as to the duties and responsibilities both of a Colonial Empire and a neutral Power.

But there is a final reason why Japan has for tho present refrained from taking the law into her own hands. She has no wish to play the Russian game and come down south to meet the Baltic Fleet. All the moral strategy at Rodjeetvensky's command is being expended just now towards that object, and ho is still counting on being able to force Togo into making reprisals. And the report of a mysterious squadron off Labuan, only about 500 miles from the present position of the Russian Admiral, renders it just possible that he has induced Togo to detach a portion of his fleet The objective of the main Russian force is, m we all know, Vladivostok. To get there he has the choice of two roads, namely, either through the Formosa Channel and tho Teu sima Straits, or east of Formosa and east of Japan and through the Tau-gara Straits, which divide the island of Yezo from the main island of Japan. If he goes by the former, he will be subjected in narrow waters to constant attacks by tho Japanese torpedo flotillas, and along the whole course of his journey north ho will be harassed and worn down by an enemy whose constant care is to avoid a fleet aotiori. If, on the other hand, he ohoosea the eastern route, he will have no friendly harbour in ease of disaster, he will be liable to attack, and those of his ships which fail to make Vladivos- tok will either be sank or captured. Togo understands the game, we may be sure, but so long as Rodjestvensky remains intact in the neighbourhood of French waters there must continue to be an amount of very disagreeably
